docs.snippet: Perhaps with the Enron trial, executives will draw the lesson that sometimes excessive greed doesn't pay....
docs.lead_paragraph: The collapse of Enron seems so long ago. Much has happened in the ensuing four years, so it is easy to forget the first in a string of corporate scandals that shook our collective trust in business leaders. For an indicted executive, conditions would seem perfect for keeping a low profile ahead of trial. So it was a surprise to see Kenneth Lay, the company's former chairman, claim in a recent speech that prosecutors disregarded the truth. Mr. Lay told a Houston audience that Enron was ''a strong, profitable, growing company even into the fourth quarter of 2001.'' That, of course, was the same quarter in which Enron declared bankruptcy.

docs.snippet: In a rare appearance, Kenneth Lay spoke to the Houston Forum and proclaimed his innocence in Enron's collapse....
docs.lead_paragraph: The well known and the powerful often appear before the Houston Forum, one of the city's elite spots for speakers. Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, gave a recent talk, as did Michael Chertoff, the homeland security secretary. But the speaker who stirred up the greatest interest was one of Houston's own: Kenneth L. Lay, the former chairman of Enron, who spoke on Tuesday.

docs.snippet: Former Gov. John G. Rowland's guilty plea leaves many questions unanswered....
docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN the word ''guilty'' was spoken by former Gov. John G. Rowland, it gave voice to the suspicions people inside and outside of government had harbored for a year. The governor had acknowledged criminal wrongdoing, agreed essentially to go to jail and had signed a document that said he and his underlings conspired to ''deprive the state of Connecticut and its citizens of the intangible right to the honest services of its Governor'' and other public officials. But while the plea deal addressed such hot-button issues as the improvements made to the governor's cottage and the unpaid chartered flights he took, it didn't deal with others such as the condo Mr. Rowland sold at an above-market price to a Connecticut developer, or the role Mr. Rowland played in deals the state made with Enron before its collapse.
docs.abstract: Article on issues that plea agreement signed by departed Connecticut Gov John Rowland did not address; while plea deal addressed improvements made to Rowland's cottage and unpaid charter flights, it did not deal with others, such as condo he sold at above-market price, role he played in deals state made with Enron before its collapse and damage to state and its residents; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Timothy Despain, a former assistant treasurer for the Enron Corporation, pleaded guilty yesterday to charges that he conspired to commit securities fraud. Mr. Despain, who worked at Enron from January 1999 to May 2002, said he helped manipulate the company's credit rating. Prosecutors agreed to recommend a reduced sentence in exchange for his cooperation in cases against other executives.

docs.lead_paragraph: An article last Sunday about the indictment of a group of former Enron executives on charges that they had lied about the existence of certain Internet technology misstated the year of an e-mail message written by Bill Collins, a former director of business development who was not implicated in any potential wrongdoing. The message, in which he lamented that the company's network software effort was fizzling, was written in 1999, not 2000.
docs.abstract: Correction of June 8 article about indictment of former Enron executives; e-mail message in question explained

docs.lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Houston has dismissed fraud and insider trading accusations brought by investors against the outside directors of Enron, saying that the plaintiffs failed to demonstrate that the board members knew about any wrongdoing. Judge Melinda Harmon of United States District Court, however, allowed the plaintiffs to continue with claims that essentially amount to accusations that the outside directors were negligent in their oversight of Enron.
docs.abstract: Federal Judge Melinda Harmon dismissed fraud and insider trading accusations brought by investors against outside directors of Enron Corp, saying plaintiffs failed to demonstrate board members knew about any wrongdoing; Harmon allows plaintiffs to continue with claims that essentially amount to accusations that outside directors were negligent in their oversight of Enron (M)

docs.snippet: A Houston magistrate has signed orders freezing a number of brokerage and bank accounts controlled by Andrew S. Fastow, the former chief financial officer of Enron, and members of his family, people involved in the case said yesterday.    The orde...
docs.lead_paragraph: A Houston magistrate has signed orders freezing a number of brokerage and bank accounts controlled by Andrew S. Fastow, the former chief financial officer of Enron, and members of his family, people involved in the case said yesterday. The orders were signed by United States Magistrate Calvin Botley late Thursday after some family members tried to move millions from one account to another, these people said. Peter Fastow, the brother of Andrew Fastow, was said to be among the family members involved. In a filing Wednesday, federal prosecutors sought to seize $500,000 in an account of Peter Fastow.
docs.abstract: Federal Magistrate Calvin Botley freezes brokerage and bank accounts controlled by former Enron Corp chief financial officer Andrew S Fastow and members of his family; acts after family members try to move millions from one account to another; money will remain in place while federal judge considers prosecutors' forfeiture bid (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ONCE upon a time, three little pigs invested in Enron. The first built his portfolio from the flourishing golden straw of Enron stock, and beamed as it doubled and tripled in value. The second chose the unseasoned lumber of Enron bonds, pleased with the generous interest they paid. The third, preferring safety to high returns, took shelter behind double-walled brick: short-term Enron notes backed by collateral and guaranteed by both a bank credit line and an insurance policy. When the wolf arrived at Enron's door last fall, forcing that once-swaggering company into bankruptcy, Enron's stock incinerated like dry grass, and its bonds smoldered down to pennies on the dollar. Not even Enron's mighty bankers expect to retrieve all of the billions in unsecured loans they made to the shattered giant.
docs.abstract: Growth and safety of asset-backed securities discussed in light of Enron collapse; holders of Enron's asset-backed commerical paper collected all $58 million owed them at time when Enron's stock and bonds plummeted; tools of so-called structured finance used to create such securities are attracting new scrutiny because they were abused by Enron to build elaborately camouflaged and booby-trapped partnerships blamed for company's collapse; diagrams; drawing (M)

headline.main: The Brick Stood Up Before. But Now?

docs.snippet: When the lawyer for the former chief executive of Enron suggested on television last Friday that the whistle-blower in the scandal was only whistling because ''she has a lucrative book deal,'' it reminded that the all-but-automatic book deal for t...
docs.lead_paragraph: When the lawyer for the former chief executive of Enron suggested on television last Friday that the whistle-blower in the scandal was only whistling because ''she has a lucrative book deal,'' it reminded that the all-but-automatic book deal for the suddenly celebrated can go well beyond mere certification and vindication of fame. It can now also be manipulated so that having a contract is an accusation. In our luminary-fascination society, the book deal is an accouterment to instant or durable celebrity, so reflexive a part of fame that when people see a new name in the news they just know a book is sure to pop up. And usually they are right. With a few notable exceptions, there is little to be said for the value of these books. Still, they have always been one of publishing's sexiest genres. People apparently are both fascinated and appalled by the large money advances they bring.
docs.abstract: Article, using Enron vice president Sherron Watkins as example, on likelihood that people who gain instant notoriety will sign lucrative book deals; notes relatively new wrinkle in such book deals is ability to discredit the newly famous; photo (M)
